4.22.18  1:10 am   How can you rotate text smoothly in a video? (e.g. upright, 1deg, 2deg, etc.) The video editor I'm using appears to only let me flip, rotate right angles, and scale, and do linear transformations not involving turning.

     you need to find another one that lets you do that, or, more likely than you think, your program might let you do it and you just haven't figured out how (maybe try holding something down while you spin it? like shift or opt or something). search online with the program name and type 'free rotate' and you should either find someone telling you how to do it or someone confirming that your program can't do it. if your program can't do it then you need to do it in another program. another insane but clever workaround, if you happen to have a graphics program (still, non-video) that does free rotate, and if you have a program to do screen recordings, you might be able to act it out in real time while recording the screen. this is an insane and strange solution but it may give you something

4.22.18  1:03 am   Can you plan radomness?

     it's difficult without special tools

4.21.18  11:57 pm   Could you explain Drop2 voicings? I'm not sure I understand

     not sure. i don't use that terminology, i just say the chord and say which bass note to use. after looking up 'drop2' i can't seem to quite discern a solid reasoning for which note to drop. i think drop2 might be more common terminology amongst music lessons than in the biz

4.21.18  8:53 pm   Do you have any tips for syncing music up to dialogues and actions in videos?

     my strategy is to make all the music myself. i understand that might not be everyone's cup of tea, because it is demanding and takes hard work, but the benefits are out of this world

     I'd love to be able to take video clips and give them a musical score where everything is in sync with the dialogue/action of what's going on the video (like if someone's walking downstairs I could have percussion hits that match the footsteps exactly, etc) are there any tricks to this?

     one good trick is to press record (with your clip synced up) and watch it and just sort of play it, after. with the right timing. so just as soon as you see the action, look away from the screen and imagine what you just saw in your head and play it synced to that, so it will be timed right, but just a bit delayed. then just go in and move it. if it's not quite right, just do it again. or if it's midi then just nudge notes to fit. fuck it, nowadays you can nudge audio notes too anyways

     Like how in your non-song vids youll have little musical cues and effects that sync up perfectly in time to graphics that are flashing on the screen or whatever.. Do you try thinking of the video as being at a certain bpm/time signature and using that for knowing when to come in, or is it just about watching the video a bunch of times and doing a bunch of takes until you get the timing right? Eventually, I wanna learn how to do animation and make my own videos, but I want to work on the music-side first by just setting music to clips from old movies or any other random stuff I can find.

4.21.18  8:27 pm   I just automatically change the key of most songs I want to sing to something more comfortable. As long as the intervals are the same, I usually don't know or care about the key or which note is A or whatever. But now I keep reading your advice to people, and you usually discuss specific notes. Have I been ignoring an important part of music this entire time?

     not quite

     Not sure if this question is clear enough...

     it makes sense, and there are certain things important about absolutes but really just range issues. ultimately does not affect the song. but getting used to a song in 1 key will make it stronger for you, vocally
